heisig_chinese_memo: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.
heisig_story: Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long drop . . . fishhook . . . a one . . . fishhook.
koohiiStory1: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.
koohiiStory2: The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I¬¥m keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.
jp_example_words:
Ê∞è(„ÅÜ„Åò): family name
Ê∞è(„Åó): family name, lineage
Ê∞èÂêç(„Åó„ÇÅ„ÅÑ): full name, identity
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your surname! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep („Åó). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks great great great great great grand pappy.

humanum_full_description_en:
Guo believes " s " word inscriptions and " dagger " (scoop spoon food) approximation, and " s " in pronunciation and also " key " the same, so the " s " is " spoon beginning of the text" of. After used to represent the "last name", "clan" in " s ."

Jinwen means the branch of the surname, †´ë's bell: "†´ë's bell". See " surname ". It is also used as the name of a married woman, preceded by her surname, which is almost Á∞ã: "Hu Zha (as) Si Bao £™ï (Á∞ã)". Also used as the official name suffix, Lingding: "Shishi", §ºàZhong: "Yinshi". Also known as " Yes ", Zhongshan Wangding: "Ku (Only) ‰øå (Fu) „ëÑ Shi (Yes) follow", which means to obey Master Fu and nanny. Zhongshan Wang Fanghu: "The clan (yes) uses the body to obscure the „öî(Áî≤)ËÉÑ, to punish the unsatisfactory." The prepositional phrase "yes" is used to connect a causal sentence to express a result or conclusion, which is equivalent to "this" "Therefore" means to put on the armor and conquer countries that do not obey the courtesy.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period represent the clan, "Tsinghua Bamboo Slips II. Jane 14: "Fei (Lian) fled east to Shanggai clan." Fei Lian was a courtier of King Zhou, meaning he fled east to Shanggai clan. "Tsinghua Jane II. "Relationship Year" Jane 102: "Jin people have the trouble of Fan family and (and) Zhongxing family. They will not disarm at the age of seven."

"Shuowen": "The name of the Bashu mountain. The name of the Bashu mountain is the name of the Kishiwaki who wants to fall °ê¶. The clan's collapse is heard hundreds of miles, pictograms, and the sound. All the family members are from the clan. Yang Xiong "Fu": "Ring Ruo Shi Kui.""

In addition, the ancient word " s ", " Jue " ( " dedication ") and nearly two glyphs mix, such as "Tsinghua Jane" in the "Jue (Jue)" mistakenly book as " s ", "Tsinghua Jane. Wong door "Jane 2-3:" to Wyeth <Jue Jue ‚îÄ> monarch "," s "should be" Jue (Jue) "misuse of the word, means to assist its monarch. See " Jue ".
humanum_short_description_en: Jia Jinwen is the first text of " Spoon ", like soup spoon (Guo Moruo). After used to represent the "last name", "clan" in " s ."

Shi
Basic explanation of words
Shi
sh√¨
In ancient times, "surname" and "clan" were used separately. The surname is the general, and the surname is the branch. Later, the surname and the surname are not distinguished, and they can be mixed.
In ancient times, they were called emperors and nobles, and later celebrities and experts: Shennong. Tai Shi's. Celsius table.

Radicals: Ê∞è  (clan)
Meaning Mnemonic
Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your surname! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
Reading Mnemonic
Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep („Åó). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.
Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks great great great great great grand pappy.
